body: I see we removed the hour limit, is this true only for bluemix but not for openwhisk?
no more hour limit anywhere.

Can we make the limits the same?
I know we have throttle tests, but they are unreliable anyway they failed a lot

Hi @archerzz, thanks for raising this issue.

Do you have a second `_` in either your Organization and/or Space name? If so, duplicate of #91 .

The limits are configurable for anyone deploying OpenWhisk. Those tests would 1. take muuuuuch longer and 2. be way more unreliable with the same limits configured everywhere. It's not sustainable to test the same limits in dev envs. as in highly scalable prod. envs.
Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/411864ce295a02a49497c9352e76a0283424f3f0.
`code` refers to the TransactionId your Transaction had and is mainly useful for the operations team to debug user issues. If you want to check if stuff went wrong, `error` will be sufficient.

@csantanapr ran into the following problem today:

overlay fs needs at least kernel 3.19 to work. the vagrant box currently deploys 3.13.
we would have to be at 4.4 for docker 1.12 complete feature set so a kernel upgrade is necessary.

I don't know if it is possible to get a higher base version of that image. Otherwise we will have to patch the kernel and reboot the VM to load the kernel during startup which means we will no longer be able to do a simple "vagrant up" to deploy everything in one go.

until we solve that we could stay on aufs for the dev envs.

The deserialization of `Binding` from a PUT request is done here: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/common/scala/src/main/scala/whisk/core/entity/WhiskPackage.scala#L192. We would have to change this to be a custom deserializer like the one used on line 143.
Any error that results from the API controller (backend) will always have both `error` and `code`. Errors that result from frontend routers will not contain `code`.

Maybe the tests need to be disable by default and only to be use in a system integration test with were there could be more control over the environment.

In a dev environment functional tests are the ones that are most important, testing limits come into play when deploying into a test or production environment, not when doing local development I should not have any limits when I run OpenWhisk in my laptop.

We could set the limit only for travis and keep running the tests only in travis CI.

These tests are the equivalent of a mini load test - they can exhibit some pathologies even with reduced limits that are important to test when working on the invoker. We should not exclude them for local development.

@domdom82 
- For native mac
  - Are there any problems using docker-machine and boot2docker?
- For ubuntu and vagrant 
  - We already use aufs [tools/ubuntu-setup/docker.sh](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/ubuntu-setup/docker.sh#L20)
  - On top we can detect the kernel version and if its 4.4 we use overlay if not then aufs during int he `docker.sh` script

Anything stopping us from just using the upcoming LTS `ubuntu/xenial64` in vagrant and be done with it? Comes with a 4.4 kernel and everything.
More future proof than building a couple of hacks into `docker.sh` imho.

nothing stopping us from using a different version of vagrant image as long it works.

The `docker.sh` is shared script used for both regular ubuntu users and vagrant.

Then it means we make Ubuntu Xenial 16.04 the minimum requirement 

How we solved this for Travis? Their default linux image already has the kernel we need to run dokcer 1.12 with overlay?

Overlay doesn't need 4.4, it needs 3.19. 4.4 is needed for full docker 1.12 security coverage (might not be able in travis aswell, so no showstopper there imho)

We also wouldn't make 16.04 the requirement but the kernel-version. Desktop users can always just upgrade the kernel while we want to supply something ootb, which happens to be 16.04 (because the earlier images ship with 3.13)

OK So 4.4 is really not required for local dev, then I would say let's start simple.

update docker.sh so it matches what we are currently using in travis
1. use overlay
2. install docker 1.12
3. update [tools/macos/README.md](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/macos/README.md) instructions for docker 1.12
After talking to @sjfink we'll create a swift:default kind following the model established by nodes:default

I had to exclude `swift3Action` and `swiftAction` task from build in the Makefile 

```
./gradlew distdocker -x :core:swift3Action:distDocker -x :core:swiftAction:distDocker
```

but other than that, everything went super smooth. As a developer I love when I can build and test a project using only a few commands and using docker for this process totally makes sense. 

I've also ran the tests @ddragosd provided and I got similar results. It's just, `4.7 Requests per seconds` doesn't seem to be a lot. Is this an expected value?

Yup - forgot to bump the limits on master (and scrapped my previous comment as a result). Rerunning. I suspect with high limits and 1 invoker, a lot of the time is going to be dominated by docker pause/unpause on containers.

The numbers above are low - I did not try to reproduce them via docker compose. Instead, I used `wskdev fresh` to build and deploy from master after lifting the `limits` in the ansible files. And then grabbed the benchmarking Makefile targets out of this pull request to run against my deployment (macbook with docker machine).

Cursory inspection of the logs shows that a lot of the time is spent in docker pause/unpause which is not necessary for the pattern of activations in this suite against one invoker. Suppressing those operations into no-ops:

I caution against reading too much into these numbers. There are other parameters to tweak and should be done relative to the host machines resource capacity.

In addition, relaxation of serial docker operations (coming when we complete adoption of docker 1.12), coalescing of load operations (in a pending pull request), and other performance optimizations in the pipeline should generally improve the results of the particular pattern of activations in this pull request.

I think there should be template for nodejs, where user have specific requirements like node modules that contain binaries (i.e. c modules), or they require some utility or operating system tool (i.e. jql).
The action will be almost identical to the actionProxy for nodejs, where node is ran once, and then on every /run the action runs in memory without the need to run a new node process.

I was going over the docs, and we document this feature for the CLI, in python is used to work.
Now with Go CLI, it doesn't I would consider this a regression from the customer/user point a view.
From the docs [packages.md#creating-a-package](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/packages.md#creating-a-package)

From the docs we document the following three commands that are broken
1. `package get PACKAGE_NAME parameters`
   
   ```
   $ wsk package get custom parameters
   ```
2. `action get ACTION_NAME parameters`
   
   ```
   $ wsk action get custom/identity parameters
   ```
3. `package get PACKAGE_NAME publish`
   
   ```
   $ wsk package get custom publish
   ```

This needs to be high on our priority list

@sjfink thx for the write-up.

a few thoughts/comments:
- re (1) are we counting the wait time in the queue as part of the total time, or does go on top of the 300/30 seconds? if it times out, which err code is returned? (should be mentioned here for the sake of completeness) ?
- re (2) as a user, i would find it weird if i got a 503, but the activation would still be running eventually. in my mind, a 503 should mean nothing got executed -- then i as a client have a clear indication that it makes sense to retry. to me, the described behavior sounds more like a 202.
- re (3) similar to my first comment -- does the time for it 'running too long' include the time it spends waiting in the queue?

Good catch on the invalid `reject(e)`, thanks! I updated the tests so that they would have caught it.

I disagree on the other changes, though. Removing the `true`s and the names of unused params seems like a recipe to run into `undefined`s later on. If JS had a `Unit` type I'd use that, but it doesn't, so I used the simplest thing that's not falsy. I added comments to help the future reader, though.

@psuter You are welcome to prefer the existing pattern, but your comment seems to indicate that you may be under the impression that promises _must_ be resolved on some value, which is not true.  In order to make my suggestion completely clear (which you are still welcome to disagree with), I have coded it up in this commit: c9918fb0f396383e74ff34656e1fb6de7ece6e70

The overall idea is that if your function doesn't produce a meaningful result that the caller is interested in, then it is reasonable to indicate success by resolving on nothing. This is a very common pattern with promises and is well documented:
http://www.2ality.com/2014/10/es6-promises-api.html
http://exploringjs.com/es6/ch_promises.html
http://www.datchley.name/es6-promises/

Thanks for the pointers. I'm still unconvinced that it's a good idea to send `undefined` values around, whatever the accepted standard is. Feel free to remove/edit and squash the changes in if you feel strongly enough about this, I won't object.

This is a great idea @krook. 
Docker Actions are one of the features that people are most impressed with but the developer experience often leaves people confused. 

I experimented with getting Go binaries running as OpenWhisk Actions and ended up creating a Go library that did everything for the user.
https://github.com/jthomas/openwhisk_go_action
https://github.com/jthomas/ow

**It would be good to compile a list of popular languages and work out the "fast path" for those developers to go from finishing their microservice to having it running as a Docker Action.** 
This might mean providing new Docker images or libraries that implement the OpenWhisk Action APIs that can use. 

**It would also be useful to document the OpenWhisk Action API using Swagger.** 
This would make it much easier to implement new runtimes without digging through existing code.

I made a Go library to help with this.
http://jamesthom.as/blog/2016/06/21/serverless-go-actions/
@mdeuser, forgot to delete that one. Should be ready to go now.
PG2 381 is blue-ish

Reading this thread got me wondering if the intent is to combine all concerns into a single database. From a microservice architecture perspective I think we could be dealing with distinct concerns that could be isolated in distinct microservices should we chose to. API Management may bring extra concerns on top of serverless ones, and I'm listing a few bellow:
- _restification_ - defining RESTful endpoints -> which I think is what this thread intends to solve, but feel free to keep me honest.
- _API Facade_ - a pattern for combining multiple endpoints into a single API . I think @mbehrendt might have referred to this when he asked _how would i add more routes to a mapping_
- _Traffic Management_ -Throttling and Rate limiting plans which are a combination of:
  - _API plans_ - rules around a single API
  - _Application plans_ - rules concerning applications that use an API
  - _User plans_ - rules concerning the end-users that use and application that consumes an API
- _Application AuthN and AuthZ_ - how do applications authenticate ? API-KEY, OAuth Tokens.
- _Users AuthZ_ - how to authorize users to consume an API. This is usually in a relation to a _User plan_. ( i.e.  applications may want to limit free subscribers more than the paid ones ) 

So if we implement all these into OW ( starting with _restification_ for now but possibly growing to the other aspects ) then would it make it easy to swap API Management implementations later ?
LGTM

Team meeting decision from Oct 4:
- we will go forward with user namespaces
- we will not mount containers read-only
- we will limit storage using overlay2 + xfs using docker 1.13 (modulo stemcell being able to mount root fs as xfs)
- if xfs not possible, pursue other solutions like io-limits or watchdogs until ext4 quota arrives
So non-root will only apply to the host. The container will still think it is running as root.
Test is added and PG2#387 is started.

Initial design proposal:
- Start docker daemon with --userns-remap=default
- This will by default start all containers in mapped uid (0 -> 100000)
- Disable mapping for regular containers such as controller, invoker etc. by passing --userns=host to docker run commands
- Action containers will run as mapped containers and thus be protected by non-root uids.

Current problem is that the ansible docker module does not yet support the --userns option. There is an open issue here https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/issues/5054

So we currently can not deploy OpenWhisk w/ this feature using ansible. As a mitigation we can fall back to using shell commands, which is uncool.
LGTM.  PG?
@csantanapr, please merge.
It might be nice to supply a [Yeoman generator](http://yeoman.io/learning/index.html) to help generate OpenWhisk actions.

Thinking longer term, it might be advisable to support .tgz files produced with the `npm pack` command. `npm pack` is smart enough to include "bundled" dependencies and exclude files that are not needed for production use (automated tests, build files, README, etc.).

This would require that `npm install` is run on the .tgz each time, however, if all the required dependencies are bundled, this command is essentially equivalent to just unpacking the .tgz. However, if all the required dependencies are not bundled, the installation will still work (albeit slower due to the overhead of fetching dependencies). At this point, using `bundledDependencies` is an optimization we can strongly encourage to the user through documentation, the aforementioned Yeoman generator, and even log messages when running actions that did not include all the required deps.

I think I'm done with this PR and is ready for your review. 

I've tested it on a Mac with Docker `1.12` and on a CentOS 7.2 with Docker `1.11.2` and everything worked fine end-to-end.  Because the Docker Compose can be used not just on Mac but on other OSs as well, I have placed it under its own folder in `./tools/docker-compose`.  

I've also created a [README](https://github.com/ddragosd/openwhisk/tree/fork/tools/docker-compose) with more details.

For organizations such as mine this proves beneficial as we're not using Ansible, we're going to deploy and run OpenWhisk on top of Apache Mesos, and the way that components such as Kafka and others get installed is different. 

Docker Compose's `YML` file makes it easy to understand the components to be executed and it makes it easy to understand the dependencies between them by looking at hints such as `depends_on` or `links`. Credits go to Docker for making not just this spec simple, but also the tooling around containers easy to use.
PG2#402 is green

Travis refused to add xenial as a supported platform for the remainder of this year. See https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/5821

So I tend to agree with @csantanapr to keep both vagrant and travis in sync. There is one problem with overlay though, because vagrant is still no 3.13 which does not support overlay. So I suggest we stick with aufs for now as it is way easier than to bump the kernel during vagrant up.

On second note we will be having fun in the test cases that are about to use things like `--pids-limit` to protect from forkbombs. Features like these only work at 4.3 and above so we will have to skip them if the kernel does not support it. I have tested locally and Docker is fine with it. It will print a warning and go on without the feature.

We will have to hop on to docker_container anyway, even though it does not yet support all features. Hopefully they will fix https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/issues/5054 at some point soon. The old docker module is a dead-end anyway.

This behavior is due to the Windows cmd command processor.  Single quotes are not treated like double quotes, but are instead treated pretty much like any other character.  So, on Windows systems, arguments requiring quoting should use double quotes.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24173825/what-does-single-quote-do-in-windows-batch-files

You can also validate this with a simple echoargs.bat file

```
@echo %0
@echo %1
@echo %2
@echo %3
```

```
>echoargs '1 2 3'
echoargs
`1
2
3`
```

```
>echoargs "1 2 3"
echoargs
"1 2 3"
ECHO is on.
ECHO is on.
```

Travis issues with swift - retrying.

Updated the messages based on your suggestions. We need to include `LIMIT` in the messages so that the help will show that an argument is expected after the flag. For instance, `-l, --logsize LIMIT          the maximum log size LIMIT in MB for the action (default 10)`
The way I see it, supporting `.tgz` could be part of this PR, but supporting `npm install` seems beyond its scope.

PG1 #675 greeny beeny.

> The way I see it, supporting .tgz could be part of this PR, but supporting npm install seems beyond its scope.

I agree, and I even think that supporting `.tgz` without `npm install` may be more confusing than valuable. In this way, we may be able to say `.zip` is for completely self-contained archives, and `.tgz` is for using with `npm install`.
